Robichaud v. United States Gypsum Co., C.raw_text: Robichaud v. United States Gypsum Co., Conn. & Mass. negligence principles applied;
Robichaud v. United States Gypsum Co., C.proposition: See, e.g., (representative authorities) Robichaud v. United States Gypsum Co., Conn. & Mass. negligence principles applied; Byrne v. City of Boston (premises liability principles); and other Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court decisions discussing landowner duties, foreseeability, and proximate causation in negligence claims — see e.g., SJC decisions on negligence and premises liability addressing duty and foreseeability as elements of liability.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf is a leading tort case articulating core negligence concepts of duty, breach, causation, and foreseeability. Cardozo’s opinion focuses on the relational nature of duty and negligence, the requirement of a legally protected interest, and the role of foreseeability in defining the scope of duty and risk. While it does not systematically lay out all elements as a Restatement would, it is properly cited as a foundational authority for those general tort propositions, especially duty and foreseeable harm.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “Negligence is not actionable unless it involves the invasion of a legally protected interest, the violation of a right. ‘Proof of negligence in the air, so to speak, will not do’… ‘In every instance, before negligence can be predicated of a given act, back of the act must be sought and found a duty to the individual complaining, the observance of which would have averted or avoided the injury’… The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension.”
